Award.AwardTitle: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Tackling Disorder and Ensemble Broadening in Materials Made of Semiconductor Nanostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: In modern science and technology, semiconducting materials play an enormous role in solid-state lighting, photovoltaics, light harvesting, and electronics. The work performed in this project will help unlock the full potential of nano-engineered semiconductors currently hidden by the effects of disorder. The proposed work will develop new experimental and theoretical techniques that eliminate negative effects due to non-uniform particle size and shape. The nanoscale semiconductors developed in this project will be used for color enhancement and energy efficiency improvement of television and electronic displays, light detectors, solar cells, and printable electronic circuits. The program will attract undergraduate and graduate students, and post-doctoral scholars who will be trained and prepared for academic and industrial careers. The PIs will also continue to integrate outreach into local programs, taking part in science club initiatives and demonstrations that focus on hands-on science experiences for public school students. The PIs will create and make publicly available a series of lecture notes for graduate students explaining computational stochastic methods to reduce the language barrier frequently experienced by quantum chemists working with this formalism.

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: This research program will focus on the chemistry and physics of colloidal semiconducting nanoplatelets (NPLs), a novel class of quantum confined semiconductors combining beneficial aspects of the electronic structure of quantum wells and quantum dots. NPLs represent a promising platform to enter a new regime of modular materials, resonant couplings, and coherent transport phenomena. Experimental and theoretical efforts will build upon each other to achieve a fundamental understanding of optical and electronic phenomena, the role of electron-phonon coupling at the single NPL, formation of superradiant states, and charge and exciton transfer at the ensemble levels. New synthetic techniques will be developed to fabricate unprecedented NPL heterostructures. Accurate computational tools based on the notion of stochastic orbitals will be introduced to uncover the interplay between moderate and strong electron-hole correlation effects. Theoretical models will be benchmarked to the optical and electronic properties of NPLs measured by steady-state and transient techniques. Charge and exciton transport in assemblies of NPLs will be iteratively predicted and measured in order to gain a deep understanding of the emergent phenomena. The collaborative effort will provide means to develop new functional materials, uncover their properties, and reveal emergent behavior in the regime of strong electronic coupling. Beyond NPLs, the anticipated development of synthetic methods, optical techniques, and large-scale developed computational tools will impact broad areas of nanomaterials (graphene, nanoribbons) where strong correlation-induced confinement governs emergent electronic properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanostructured semiconductor materials offer a promising platform to discover novel phenomena and have begun to deliver a large diversity of electronic and optoelectronic applications. However, until quite recently, progress has been impeded by the complexity associated with disorder and inhomogeneity of frequently investigated structures in this category that include spherical nanocrystals, cubes, and nanowires, among others. The lack of atomistic control during nanomaterial synthesis severely limited our ability to perform “total-synthesis” of sophisticated nano-heterostructures with precisely arranged multiple components and fine-tuned properties.

In this program, we have developed an approach for designing and investigating nanostructured materials with virtually no inhomogeneous broadening effects. We introduced a general synthetic strategy which largely circumvented the limitations of traditional colloidal synthesis. Colloidal Atomic Layer Deposition (c-ALD) with stationary reactant phases allows significant reduction of inhomogeneity for nanomaterials without compromising their structural perfection. The approach is inspired by the recent synthesis of colloidal nanoplatelets (NPLs, which resemble playing cards) with precise atomic control over the thickness dimension that largely prescribes electronic and optical properties. NPLs thus offer a new regime of modular materials that can exhibit processes which are normally absent or hidden in other nanomaterials, which include resonant couplings, strong optical gain and lasing, and coherent transport phenomena.

Our approach coupled advanced theory, synthesis, and characterization methods. Newly developed theoretical models were benchmarked for the optical and electronic properties of NPLs measured by steady-state and transient absorption techniques, and then used to predict the area and thickness dependence on exciton-exciton annihilation (a highly important property for light-emitting devices) and the effects of dielectric confinement in 2D NPLs (significant for charge transport phenomena). Through close coupling of theoretical modeling and experimentation, we, for example, produced key insights related to the fundamental size of electron-hole pairs within the plane of NPLs using NSF’s National High Magnetic Field Lab. The pulsed fields up to 60 Tesla permitted precise quantification of diamagnetic shifts, which are spectral changes in absorption related to the magnetic field squeezing the exciton. We found these sizes track largely with NPL thickness and lateral area (Figure 1) and the size of excitons impacts optical gain and lasing processes as well as aids in pictures of in-plane exciton diffusivity and charge transfer processes relevant to energy-related applications of nanomaterials.

By examining CdSe NPLs using either optical excitation or electrical reduction, we could observe intersubband absorptions at remarkably high energy (near 1 eV) relative to physically grown 2D quantum wells. These absorptions of the electron to higher lying states in the conduction band are size tunable thought important regions of the telecommunications bands, and suggest that NPLs can serve as optical or electrical switches to rapidly route light through fiber networks (see Figure 2).

The collaborative effort provided means to develop new functional materials, uncover their properties, and reveal emergent behavior in the regime of strong electronic coupling. In the last several years, we have developed new synthetic techniques to fabricate unprecedented NPL heterostructures (Figure 3) along with accurate computational tools based on the notion of stochastic orbitals to uncover the interplay between moderate and strong electron-hole correlation effects.  Beyond NPLs, the anticipated development of synthetic methods, optical techniques, and large-scale computational tools has impacted broad areas of nanomaterials, where strong correlation-induced confinement governs emergent electronic properties.

Our program contributed in significant ways to broader impact. Our efforts in this Collaborate program spanned three Universities and contributed to the training of several graduate students including with significant interaction of each supported student with each PI. We held open-to-the-public, well-attended workshops that both described and discussed technological opportunities and progress of the research project, educated others as to how to accomplish multi-disciplinary research, and openly discussed potential research directions with the community. Supported students and the PIs participated in extensive and sustained outreach efforts to different segments of the populace spanning elementary school children to senior citizens, often with targeted focus on broadening participation of underrepresented groups.
